dataset/provenance:
The dataset used in this study was sourced from patients diagnosed with liver cancer at our institution between 1999 and 2019. All patient data were fully anonymized prior to analysis. The inclusion criteria required the availability of preoperative contrast-enhanced ultrasound (CEUS) images and surgical excision or biopsy with pathological examination. Exclusion criteria included the lack of histopathological evaluation, incomplete clinical data, and substandard CEUS image quality.

The final study cohort consisted of 280 patients, evenly divided between those diagnosed with hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) and intrahepatic cholangiocarcinoma (ICC), with 140 patients in each group. This cohort was randomly split into a training set of 224 patients and a validation set of 56 patients. The training set included 112 HCC patients and 112 ICC patients, while the validation set included 28 HCC patients and 28 ICC patients.

The dataset includes clinical characteristics such as sex, age, hepatitis B virus (HBV) infection status, alpha-fetoprotein (AFP) levels, and carbohydrate antigen 19-9 (CA19-9) levels. These characteristics were collected from admission records. The ultrasound images acquired included baseline US images, arterial enhancement (AE) images, and portal enhancement (PE) images. The largest liver lesion was targeted for patients with multiple lesions, and the ultrasound contrast agent Sonovue was administered to capture CEUS clips for analysis.

The dataset has not been used in previous papers by the community.
dataset/splits: The dataset was divided into two main splits: a training cohort and a validation cohort. The training cohort consisted of 224 patients, with 112 cases of hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) and 112 cases of intrahepatic cholangiocarcinoma (ICC). The validation cohort comprised 56 patients, evenly split with 28 cases of HCC and 28 cases of ICC. The patients were randomly assigned to these cohorts, ensuring a balanced distribution of the two types of liver cancer in both the training and validation sets. This split was designed to facilitate the development and evaluation of radiomics models for differentiating between HCC and ICC.
dataset/redundancy:
The dataset consisted of 280 patients, equally divided between those diagnosed with hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) and intrahepatic cholangiocarcinoma (ICC). The patients were randomly assigned to either a training cohort or a validation cohort. The training cohort included 224 patients, with an equal number of HCC and ICC cases (112 each). The validation cohort consisted of 56 patients, also evenly split between HCC and ICC (28 each).

The training and validation sets were independent, ensuring that the models were trained and tested on distinct data to avoid overfitting and to provide a reliable evaluation of their performance. This independence was enforced through random assignment, which helped in maintaining the integrity of the model evaluation process.

The distribution of the dataset in terms of patient characteristics, such as age, sex, hepatitis B virus (HBV) infection, and tumor size, showed no significant differences between the training and validation cohorts. This consistency in distribution is crucial for ensuring that the models generalize well to new, unseen data. However, notable differences were observed in the levels of alpha-fetoprotein (AFP) and carbohydrate antigen 19-9 (CA19-9) between HCC and ICC patients, which were included as clinical characteristics in the radiomics model.

Compared to previously published machine learning datasets in similar medical domains, the dataset used in this study is robust and well-balanced. The random splitting and equal representation of both HCC and ICC cases in both cohorts ensure that the models are trained and validated on representative samples, enhancing the reliability and generalizability of the results.
optimization/algorithm:
The optimization algorithm employed in our study is a random forest algorithm. This is a well-established ensemble learning method that operates by constructing multiple decision trees during training and outputting the mode of the classes (classification) or mean prediction (regression) of the individual trees.

The random forest algorithm is not new; it has been extensively used and validated in various fields, including medical imaging and radiomics. Its robustness and ability to handle high-dimensional data make it suitable for our study, which involves a large number of features extracted from ultrasound images.

The choice of random forest for our specific application in differentiating between intrahepatic cholangiocarcinoma (ICC) and hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) using contrast-enhanced ultrasound (CEUS) images was driven by its effectiveness in capturing complex relationships within the data. This algorithm was selected for its ability to provide reliable and interpretable results, which are crucial in a clinical setting.

Given that random forest is a widely recognized and established algorithm, it was not necessary to publish it in a machine-learning journal. Instead, our focus was on applying this algorithm to a novel dataset and demonstrating its utility in a specific medical context. The innovation lies in the application of the algorithm to CEUS-based ultrasomics for ICC-HCC differentiation, rather than in the algorithm itself.
optimization/meta:
The models developed in this study do not function as meta-predictors. Instead, they are individual radiomics models constructed using the random forest algorithm. Four distinct models were created: the US model, which uses ultrasound images; the CEUS model, which utilizes contrast-enhanced ultrasound images; the US + CEUS model, which combines both ultrasound and contrast-enhanced ultrasound images; and the US + CEUS + CL model, which integrates ultrasound, contrast-enhanced ultrasound images, and clinical characteristics.

Each of these models was trained and validated independently. The training cohort consisted of 224 patients, while the validation cohort included 56 patients. The models were evaluated using metrics such as the area under the receiver operating characteristic curve (AUC), accuracy, sensitivity, specificity, and precision. The performance of these models was compared to determine the most efficient one for differentiating between hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) and intrahepatic cholangiocarcinoma (ICC).

The US + CEUS + CL model demonstrated the highest AUC values, indicating superior diagnostic accuracy. This model's performance was also compared to the diagnostic abilities of radiologists with varying levels of experience, showing that it outperformed less-experienced radiologists and matched the accuracy of the most experienced radiologist.

In summary, the models are standalone radiomics models, each utilizing different combinations of imaging and clinical data, and they were trained and validated on independent datasets.
optimization/encoding:
The data encoding and preprocessing for the machine-learning algorithm involved several key steps. Initially, ultrasound images were acquired using convex array scanners with a frequency range of 1.0 to 6.0 MHz. For patients with multiple liver lesions, the largest lesion was targeted. The ultrasound contrast agent, Sonovue, was administered, and CEUS clips were recorded for 90 seconds following the injection. Additional images were captured at 120 seconds and subsequently every 60 seconds until the contrast washed out.

The ultrasound images obtained included baseline US images, arterial enhancement (AE) images showing peak enhancement of the target lesion, and portal enhancement (PE) images captured at 120 seconds. These images were manually segmented along the tumor contour by an abdominal radiologist with experience in liver CEUS, and the regions of interest (ROIs) were validated by a senior radiologist.

Image preprocessing and feature extraction were performed using the Pyradiomics package. A total of 828 features were extracted from each ROI. The significance of each feature was calculated using XGBoost, and the top 20 significant features were selected for further analysis. The relationships among these features were assessed using the Spearman correlation coefficient, and features with a correlation coefficient greater than 0.8 were discarded to avoid redundancy. The remaining features were chosen for subsequent analysis.

A random forest algorithm was utilized to establish the radiomics model. Four models were developed and compared to determine the most efficient one: the US model (using US images), the CEUS model (using AE and PE images), the US + CEUS model (combining US, AE, and PE images), and the US + CEUS + CL model (integrating US, AE, and PE images with clinical characteristics). The number of features selected varied for each model, with 13 features for the US model, 15 for the CEUS model, 13 for the US + CEUS model, and 21 for the US + CEUS + CL model.

optimization/fitting:
In our study, we employed a robust methodology to ensure that our models were neither overfitting nor underfitting the data. The number of parameters in our models was indeed larger than the number of training points, which is a common scenario in radiomics studies due to the high dimensionality of the feature space.

To mitigate overfitting, we utilized several strategies. Firstly, we selected the top 20 significant features using XGBoost, which helped in reducing the dimensionality of the feature space. Secondly, we assessed the relationships among these features using the Spearman correlation coefficient and discarded less significant features with a correlation coefficient greater than 0.8. This step ensured that we retained only the most informative and independent features. Additionally, we employed a random forest algorithm to establish the radiomics model, which is known for its ability to handle high-dimensional data and reduce overfitting through ensemble learning.

To address underfitting, we developed and compared four different models: the US model, the CEUS model, the US + CEUS model, and the US + CEUS + CL model. Each model incorporated different combinations of imaging and clinical data, allowing us to capture a wide range of patterns and relationships in the data. Furthermore, we evaluated the models using metrics such as AUC, accuracy, sensitivity, specificity, and precision in both training and test cohorts. This comprehensive evaluation ensured that our models were generalizable and not overly simplistic.

In summary, by carefully selecting features, using ensemble learning, and thoroughly evaluating our models, we were able to balance the complexity of our models and ensure that they were neither overfitting nor underfitting the data.
optimization/regularization:
In our study, we employed several techniques to prevent overfitting and ensure the robustness of our models. One of the key methods used was feature selection. We initially extracted a large number of features from the medical images. To avoid overfitting, we used XGBoost to calculate the significance of each feature and selected only the top 20 significant features for further analysis. This step helped in reducing the dimensionality of the data and focusing on the most relevant features.

Additionally, we assessed the relationships among the selected features using the Spearman correlation coefficient. Features with a Spearman correlation coefficient greater than 0.8 were considered highly correlated, and the less significant ones were discarded. This process further refined our feature set, ensuring that we retained only the most informative and independent features.

To build our radiomics models, we utilized a random forest algorithm, which is known for its ability to handle high-dimensional data and reduce overfitting through ensemble learning. The random forest algorithm aggregates the predictions of multiple decision trees, each trained on a different subset of the data, thereby improving the model's generalization performance.

We developed four different models: the US model (using US images), the CEUS model (using AE and PE images), the US + CEUS model (combining US, AE, and PE images), and the US + CEUS + CL model (integrating US, AE, and PE images with clinical characteristics). By comparing the performance of these models, we were able to determine the most efficient one and ensure that our findings were not due to overfitting to a specific type of data.

In summary, our approach to preventing overfitting involved feature selection using XGBoost and Spearman correlation coefficient, as well as the use of a random forest algorithm for model building. These techniques helped us to create robust and generalizable models for differentiating between HCC and ICC.

model/output:
The model developed in this study is a classification model. It is designed to differentiate between two types of liver cancer: hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) and intrahepatic cholangiocarcinoma (ICC). The model utilizes various imaging features extracted from ultrasound (US) and contrast-enhanced ultrasound (CEUS) images, along with clinical characteristics, to classify the type of liver cancer present in a patient.

The performance of the model was evaluated using metrics such as the area under the receiver operating characteristic curve (AUC), accuracy, sensitivity, specificity, and precision. These metrics indicate that the model is effective in distinguishing between HCC and ICC, with the US + CEUS + CL model achieving the highest AUC values in both the validation and test cohorts.

The decision curve analysis further supports the clinical utility of the model, showing that it provides a significant benefit in terms of net benefits at different risk thresholds. This suggests that the model can be a valuable tool for clinicians in making diagnostic decisions.

The model was established using a random forest algorithm, which is well-suited for classification tasks. The features used in the model were selected based on their significance, as calculated using XGBoost, and their relationships, as assessed using the Spearman correlation coefficient. This ensures that the model is built on a robust set of features that are relevant to the classification task.

In summary, the model is a classification model that effectively differentiates between HCC and ICC using US and CEUS images, along with clinical characteristics. It has been validated and shown to provide significant clinical benefits.
evaluation/method:
The evaluation of the developed models involved a comprehensive assessment of their predictive efficacy using several metrics and comparisons. Four distinct models were created: the US model (using ultrasound images), the CEUS model (using arterial enhancement and portal enhancement images), the US + CEUS model (combining ultrasound, arterial enhancement, and portal enhancement images), and the US + CEUS + CL model (integrating ultrasound, arterial enhancement, and portal enhancement images with clinical characteristics).

To evaluate these models, receiver operating characteristic (ROC) curves were plotted, and key metrics such as the area under the curve (AUC), accuracy, sensitivity, specificity, and precision were calculated for both training and test cohorts. These metrics provided a robust evaluation of each model's performance in distinguishing between hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) and intrahepatic cholangiocarcinoma (ICC).

Additionally, the diagnostic performances of the radiomic models were compared with those of three radiologists who had varying levels of experience in liver contrast-enhanced ultrasound (CEUS). The radiologists reviewed the images of all cases and made diagnoses. The DeLong test was used to compare the diagnostic performances, ensuring a statistically sound comparison.

A decision curve analysis was also conducted to assess the clinical utility of the models. This analysis quantified the net benefits at different risk thresholds, providing insights into the practical value of the models in clinical settings.

Statistical analysis was performed using SPSS 22.0, with continuous variables expressed as means ± standard deviation and categorical variables reported as numbers and percentages. Appropriate statistical tests, such as the χ2 test, Student’s t-test, Mann-Whitney U test, Wilcoxon test, and Fisher’s exact test, were used to analyze clinical features for statistical differences between the training and test cohorts. The reported statistical significance levels were all two-sided, with P values of less than 0.05 considered statistically significant. Calibration diagnostic accuracy was expressed as the AUC, and the resulting specificity, sensitivity, positive predictive value, and negative predictive value were calculated. The DeLong test was used to compare AUC values, ensuring a rigorous evaluation of the models' performance.
evaluation/measure:
In our study, we evaluated the predictive efficacy of our radiomics models using several key performance metrics. These metrics were calculated for both the training and test cohorts to ensure a comprehensive assessment of model performance.

The primary metric reported was the Area Under the Receiver Operating Characteristic Curve (AUC), which provides a measure of the model's ability to distinguish between the two classes (HCC and ICC). Alongside the AUC, we also reported sensitivity, specificity, accuracy, positive predictive value (PPV), and negative predictive value (NPV). These metrics offer a detailed view of the model's performance across different aspects.

Sensitivity, also known as the true positive rate, indicates the proportion of actual positives that are correctly identified by the model. Specificity, or the true negative rate, measures the proportion of actual negatives that are correctly identified. Accuracy provides an overall measure of the model's correctness, while PPV and NPV offer insights into the precision of positive and negative predictions, respectively.

These metrics are widely used in the literature for evaluating the performance of diagnostic models, ensuring that our results are comparable with other studies in the field. The inclusion of these metrics allows for a thorough evaluation of the models' diagnostic capabilities and their potential clinical utility.
evaluation/comparison:
In our study, we developed and compared four distinct radiomics models to evaluate their performance in differentiating between intrahepatic cholangiocarcinoma (ICC) and hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC). These models included the US model (using ultrasound images), the CEUS model (using arterial enhancement and portal enhancement images), the US + CEUS model (combining ultrasound, arterial enhancement, and portal enhancement images), and the US + CEUS + CL model (integrating ultrasound, arterial enhancement, portal enhancement images with clinical characteristics).

To assess the predictive efficacy of each model, we plotted receiver operating characteristic (ROC) curves and calculated key metrics such as the area under the curve (AUC), accuracy, sensitivity, specificity, and precision for both training and test cohorts. These metrics provided a comprehensive evaluation of each model's performance.

Additionally, we compared the diagnostic performances of our radiomic models with those of three radiologists who had varying levels of experience in liver contrast-enhanced ultrasound (CEUS). The radiologists' diagnostic performances were evaluated using the DeLong test, which allowed us to statistically compare the AUC values of the models and the radiologists.

Furthermore, we conducted a decision curve analysis to assess the clinical utility of the models by quantifying the net benefits at different risk thresholds. This analysis helped us determine the practical value of each model in a clinical setting.

While we did not compare our methods to publicly available benchmarks or simpler baselines, our study focused on internal comparisons among different model configurations to identify the most effective approach for differentiating ICC from HCC. The results demonstrated that the US + CEUS + CL model achieved the highest AUC, indicating superior diagnostic performance compared to the other models and experienced radiologists.
evaluation/confidence:
The evaluation of our models included a comprehensive assessment of performance metrics, which were accompanied by confidence intervals to provide a measure of their reliability. The area under the receiver operating characteristic curve (AUC) was a key metric, and it was reported with 95% confidence intervals for each model across different cohorts. This allowed for a clear understanding of the precision of our AUC estimates.

Statistical significance was a crucial aspect of our evaluation. We employed the DeLong test to compare the AUC values of different models, ensuring that any claimed superiority was backed by robust statistical evidence. This test helped us determine whether the differences in AUC between models were statistically significant, thereby validating the enhanced performance of models that incorporated additional information, such as CEUS and clinical data.

Moreover, we conducted decision curve analysis to assess the clinical utility of our models. This analysis quantified the net benefits at different risk thresholds, providing insights into the practical value of our models in real-world clinical settings. The decision curves demonstrated that models incorporating more information, such as US, CEUS, and clinical characteristics, offered greater benefits compared to simpler models.

In summary, our evaluation was rigorous and statistically sound, with confidence intervals and significance tests supporting the claims of superior performance for our more comprehensive models. This approach ensures that our findings are reliable and applicable in clinical practice.
